Another reason for their importance is that they generate the algebra of all symmetric polynomials, but we will not need this fact. Our goal is to connect the elementary symmetric polynomials with the symmetric polynomials.

One can verify that

Lemma 6.35 (Newton's formulas) For $k=1,\ldots,n$ we have  

$$
k e_{k}=\sum_{j=1}^{k}(-1)^{j-1}e_{k-j}p_{j}.
$$  

Proof From (6.6) it follows that  

$$
\sum_{j=0}^{n}(-1)^{j}e_{n-j}\omega_{i}^{j}=0,\;\;\;i=1,\ldots,n.
$$  

Summing up over all $i$ we obtain (6.8) for $k=n$. The case where $k<n$ follows easily from this one, basically we are facing only a problem in notation. The one that we are using suggests that $n$ is fixed and $k$ varies. While this setting is natural in view of applications, in the proof that follows it is inconvenient to regard $n$ as fixed. Let us therefore write, just for the purpose of this proof, $e_{k,n}$ for $e_{k}$ and $p_{j,n}$ for $p_{j}$. Our goal is to show that the polynomial  

$$
P:=k e_{k,n}-\sum_{j=1}^{k}(-1)^{j-1}e_{k-j,n}p_{j,n}
$$  

is 0. Note that for any $i,j\leq k$ we have  

$$
\begin{array}{r}{e_{i,n}(\omega_{1},\dots,\omega_{k},0,\dots,0)=e_{i,k}(\omega_{1},\dots,\omega_{k}),}\\ {\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad}\\ {p_{j,n}(\omega_{1},\dots,\omega_{k},0,\dots,0)=p_{j,k}(\omega_{1},\dots,\omega_{k}).}\end{array}
$$  

Since (6.8) holds for $n=k$, it follows that $P(\omega_{1},.\,.\,,\omega_{k},0,.\,.\,.\,,0)=0.$ This means that $P$ does not contain nonzero monomials in $\omega_{1},.\,.\,.\,,\,\omega_{k}$.
